html:
Mosquito Repellent for Cuba: The Bulk Buyer's Survival Guide

Look, mosquitoes in Cuba aren't playing around. Between dengue, Zika, and just the sheer annoyance of being eaten alive during every family gathering, sending effective repellent is basically an act of love. But here's the thing—not all repellents are created equal, and when you're buying in bulk to ship, you need stuff that actually works in tropical conditions, won't melt in a hot container, and gives your family enough protection to last. Let me break down what's worth your money and what's just expensive water.

Understanding Your Options: DEET vs. Picaridin vs. Permethrin

Before we get into specific products, you need to understand the three main players. DEET is the old reliable—98% DEET products will stop almost anything that flies or crawls. It's been around since the 1940s and it works. The downside? It can damage plastics and synthetic fabrics, and some people hate the smell. Picaridin is the newer kid—just as effective as DEET for most situations, doesn't destroy your sunglasses, and feels less greasy. Then there's Permethrin, which is a whole different approach: you spray it on clothes and gear (never skin), and it kills mosquitoes on contact. It lasts through multiple washes.

For Cuba specifically, I'd recommend a combo approach. Body spray for exposed skin, permethrin-treated clothes for the heavy-duty protection. Your family will thank you during those evening hours when the mosquitoes come out in force. And trust me—during rainy season in Havana or anywhere in the provinces, they come out in force.

The Quick Answer

If you're sending one thing, make it the Sawyer Permethrin 24oz bottle ($$). It treats multiple sets of clothes, lasts 6 weeks or 6 washes per treatment, and stretches further than any body spray. Pair it with a couple bottles of Repel 100 ($) for skin application and your family is genuinely protected.

See Sawyer Permethrin on Amazon

Body Sprays: What Goes on Skin

4.6★ 465 reviews $

Repel 100 Insect Repellent, 4oz Pump Spray

This is the nuclear option. 98.11% DEET means nothing—and I mean nothing—is biting through this. Ten hours of protection in the harshest conditions. The 4oz size is perfect for shipping: substantial enough to last but won't blow your weight limits. One bottle per person should last a month of daily use.

Fair warning: it's strong stuff. Don't spray near plastics or synthetic fabrics—it'll damage them. But for walking through tall grass, evening cookouts, or just surviving the patio? Unbeatable.

VERDICT: The serious repellent for serious mosquito problems. Best value per ounce.

Check Price on Amazon
4.6★ 465 reviews $

Repel 100, 1oz Travel Size

Same 98% DEET formula in a pocket-friendly size. These are brilliant for distributing among family members—everyone gets their own bottle to carry. Great for kids heading to school, workers in the fields, or just keeping one in every bag.

The per-ounce cost is higher than the 4oz, but the convenience factor is real. Buy a few of these alongside the bigger bottles.

VERDICT: Perfect for personal carry. Buy these as add-ons, not your main supply.

Check Price on Amazon
4.5★ 455 reviews $$

Ben's 100 Tick & Insect Repellent, 3.4oz (2 Pack)

Here's something the Repel doesn't offer: this is alcohol-free. That matters if someone in the family has sensitive skin or if you're applying to kids. Same 98% DEET protection, gentler delivery. The 2-pack at $$ is decent value.

Ben's has a cult following among hikers and outdoor professionals. The formula feels less harsh without sacrificing effectiveness. If the Repel smell bothers anyone, try this instead.

VERDICT: The gentler high-DEET option. Worth it for sensitive skin.

Check Price on Amazon
4.6★ 465 reviews $

OFF! Deep Woods Travel Size, 2.5oz Aerosol

The familiar brand everyone recognizes. This aerosol version has a dry, non-greasy formula that people actually like wearing. Lower DEET concentration (25%) means you might need to reapply more often, but for everyday use it's fine.

One thing: aerosols can be tricky for shipping—some carriers have restrictions. Check before you buy a whole case. The pump sprays are safer bets for bulk shipping.

VERDICT: Good for light use, but check shipping rules on aerosols first.

Check Price on Amazon

The DEET-Free Options: Picaridin & Plant-Based

4.5★ 455 reviews $$

Sawyer Picaridin Spray, 3oz (Pack of 2)

If anyone in the family refuses to use DEET—and some people really hate it—Picaridin is your answer. At 20% concentration, it matches DEET's effectiveness for mosquitoes. Won't damage plastics or fabrics. Doesn't have that chemical smell. Just works.

The 2-pack at $$ gives you 6oz total of premium repellent. Sawyer makes quality stuff—they're the go-to brand for serious outdoor people. This is what I'd send for anyone who's complained about DEET in the past.

VERDICT: Best DEET alternative. Same protection, better feel.

Check Price on Amazon
4.5★ 455 reviews $$

Sawyer Picaridin Continuous Spray, 6oz (Pack of 2)

Same great Picaridin formula in a continuous spray can. The advantage here is coverage—you can spray your back, hit hard-to-reach spots, and apply more evenly. The 2-pack gives you 12oz total, which is serious volume for the price.

Again, check shipping restrictions on aerosols. But if you can get these through, they're the most user-friendly option for family members who aren't great at thorough application.

VERDICT: Best coverage, best value in the Picaridin category.

Check Price on Amazon
4.5★ 455 reviews $

Sawyer Picaridin Lotion, 4oz

The lotion format is interesting—you apply it like sunscreen, so you know exactly where you've covered. No overspray, no waste. Some people find this more pleasant than sprays, especially for face and neck application.

At $ for 4oz, this is actually the best per-ounce value in the Picaridin lineup. The trade-off is application time—it takes longer than a quick spray. Good for careful, thorough protection.

VERDICT: Best value Picaridin. Ideal for face and careful application.

Check Price on Amazon
4.4★ 445 reviews $

Repel Plant-Based Lemon Eucalyptus, 4oz (Pack of 2)

The "natural" option that actually works. Oil of Lemon Eucalyptus (OLE) is CDC-recommended for mosquito protection—this isn't just essential oil nonsense. The catch? It needs reapplication every 2-3 hours instead of the 10 hours you get from DEET.

The 2-pack at $ is excellent value. Smells pleasant (like a spa, honestly), and people who hate chemical repellents will actually use this. For kids or anyone with chemical sensitivities, this is the move.

VERDICT: Best natural option. Reapply often, but it genuinely works.

Check Price on Amazon

Clothing Treatment: The Game Changer

Okay, here's where we get serious. Permethrin-treated clothing is honestly the most effective mosquito protection you can send. It doesn't go on skin—you spray it on clothes, let them dry, and the treatment lasts through 6 washes. Mosquitoes that land on treated fabric? They die. Not repelled. Dead.

4.6★ 465 reviews $$

Sawyer Permethrin, 24oz - TOP PICK

This is the one. Twenty-four ounces treats approximately 4 complete outfits or 2 tents plus gear. One bottle can protect an entire family's work clothes for weeks. The value here is insane compared to buying treated clothing pre-made.

Application is simple: spray clothes until damp, hang to dry for 2 hours, done. Works on cotton, synthetics, even mosquito nets. For anyone working outdoors, in agriculture, or just dealing with heavy mosquito areas—this is the single most effective thing you can send.

VERDICT: Best overall value. This is what I'd send if I could only send one thing.

Check Price on Amazon
4.6★ $

Sawyer Permethrin, 9oz

The starter size. Treats about 1-2 outfits. Good if you're testing or have limited shipping space, but the 24oz is much better value per ounce.

See Price
4.6★ $$$

Sawyer
